Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: The ecology and evolution of cooperation in a tropical bird
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will be a synthesis of 20 years of research on the ecology and evolution of Long-tailed Manakins. These Neotropical birds have a lek mating system, in which clustered males court females. Their leks are unique in the animal kingdom because pairs of unrelated males (alphas and betas) cooperate for coordinated song and dance displays. If a mating occurs, it is always by the alpha. Because the cooperation involves neither kin selection nor reciprocity, an evolutionary puzzle arises. Why should betas help alphas? The PI will synthesize his results in two major ways: 1) by using models borrowed from sociology to explore the complex social relationships among males; 2) with analyses of male interactions, using 18 years of records of individually marked birds. He will generate: 1) a book summarizing and synthesizing his research on this species, 2) an edited book, in which researchers describe the many ways manakins serve as models for understanding tropical biodiversity.

Understanding empirical conditions that promote cooperation among unrelated individuals could stimulate insights into conditions that foster alternatives to violence in humans. Increasingly, human societies are aggregations of unrelated individuals plagued by violent interactions. Sociologists and psychologists have often used insights from non-human animals to model processes in humans. The simpler social system of the manakins should be useful in suggesting conditions that promote cooperation in unexpected contexts, such as the apparent paradox that males that should compete intensely for mates, instead act cooperatively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bop till you drop: the extraordinary social system of a small tropical bird.

Long-tailed Manakins are small tropical birds with a lek mating system, meaning that males cluster to court females and the females then choose their mates from among the assembled males based on their plumage or displays.  In many lek mating systems, some males are very successful, while many or most males do not mate at all.  In Long-tailed Manakins, high unanimity of female choice (top males may mate with as many as 100 females in a year) has created an extraordinary and unique social organization –unrelated males form queues for courtship display. In each queue, the top two males sing in unison and perform a coordinated backwards leapfrog dance over each other. For many years I have explored the ecological and evolutionary factors that drive this unusual combination of cooperation (within queues) and competition (among queues). One of the most important factors seems to be that, because females choose just one or a few older males (10 or older), few options exist for present mating success by young males (less than 8 years old). Their best option is therefore to spend their youth helping other males build a reputation for a site to which females return year after year. They then wait patiently in an age-based queue, so as eventually to reap the rewards of their cooperation. The goal of this project was to synthesize almost 20 years of research in a number of coherent larger frameworks. One way of doing this was by using social network analysis. Social network analysis quantifies the social connections among large numbers of network members (in this case, male manakins). An example of an exciting finding is that young males that are well connected (assessed by measuring how often a male lies along the various paths through the network) are five times more likely to be successful (five years later) than males that were less well-connected as youngsters. Surprisingly, being well connected seems to matter for young males trying to work their way upward, but is not as important for older, already successful males. Another use of social network analysis has been to understand the circumstances that, very rarely, lead to a breakdown of the normally cooperative queue structure. Here, analyses reveal that a key factor seems to be unusually rapid turnover in highly successful queues with a large set of site-faithful females. If several top males die in quick succession, a power vacuum results; that vacuum seems to draw in older contenders from other queues. Because these males from different queues do not know each other well, they have not worked out their relative dominance ranks, and open conflict results. In the normal scheme of things, in contrast, each male in the queue knows his place exactly – engaging in conflict would only drive away females and hurt the very reputation drives the queue system. One of the pleasures of this award was the opportunity to try to condense my research in a (relatively) readable form, aimed at undergraduates, that sought to convey the twin excitements of tropical fieldwork and sophisticated technical analyses, such as social network analyses (math can be fun!). If you found this sketch comprehensible (congratulations!) you might enjoy reading further in: McDonald, D.B. 2014. Studying lifelong male-male partnerships in a tropical bird. Pages 99-120 In Animal Behavior: How and Why Animals Do the Things They Do, Vol. 3 (K. Yasukawa, editor). Praeger, Santa Barbara, CA. If you would like to see manakin research in action, my graduate students and I are now studying Golden-winged Manakins in Ecuador.  Check my website http://www.uwyo.edu/dbmcd/ecuador/ecuador.html for information on trips to Ecuador.
